Madagascar - Projet de Developpement du
            Sous-Secteur du Coton

abstracts.cdata!:
The Cotton Development Project in
            Madgascar was implemented. The Bank failed to see that the
            increase in production through area expansion had
            excessively stretched the Hasy Madgascar, Cotton Marketing
            Parastatal (HASYMA) supervision capacities, which affected
            yields and farmers' repayments. The Borrower has been
            fairly supportive of the project, particularly during the
            expansion phase. The project is rated as unsatisfactory. The
            project failed to set up a viable institution for the cotton
            sub-sector, as the financial situation of HASYMA has
            considerably worsened during the project period and this
            parastatal is still technically insolvent. The experience
            from this project shows that: the project was aimed from the
            beginning at providing more domestically produced cotton
            fiber to the local textile mills, as such, it fitted with
            the prevailing self-sufficiency and exchange rate policies.
            The continuous presence of a cotton specialist in
            supervision missions could have detected these deficiencies
            at an earlier stage; and In-depth studies were carried out
            on the restructuring of HASYMA following the 1986-1987
            events, with few results despite donor pressure for change.
            It was agreed, however, that HASYMA could take independent
            marketing decisions for its fiber, and export cotton if it
            could obtain better prices.
